title: Meta's AI Revolution and the Future of AR Glasses
description: In this episode, we dive into Meta's Q3 2024 earnings call highlights, focusing on their AI breakthroughs, the adoption of Llama models, and the future of AR glasses. We discuss how these innovations are poised to shape the industry, bringing transformative experiences to both consumers and enterprises alike.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into the recent Meta Q3 2024 earnings call and some of the incredible strides they're making with AI, augmented reality, and computing. There’s a lot to unpack here, from record-breaking user numbers to AI-driven advancements that might just define the next phase of technology as we know it.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Mark Zuckerberg mentioned that Meta now has over 3.2 billion people using at least one of their apps each day. That's an astonishing number. And with Meta AI and Llama rapidly becoming key parts of the industry, we’re seeing how Meta is positioning itself not only as a leader in social networking but also as a major force in AI development.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Let's start by talking about Meta's AI efforts. Meta AI, their generative AI assistant, has now surpassed 500 million monthly active users. Imagine the kind of scale that requires. Improvements in their AI-driven feed and video recommendations have boosted engagement across both Facebook and Instagram—up 8% and 6% respectively this year. Those aren’t just numbers; they’re proof of how AI is transforming user experience on a massive scale.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And it doesn't stop there. Llama, their open-source language model, is quickly becoming an industry standard. This quarter, Meta released Llama 3.2, which includes on-device models and open-source multimodal capabilities. They've even been working with the U.S. government to integrate Llama into public sector operations. Zuckerberg sees Llama as a pivotal piece of Meta's strategy, making AI more customizable and cost-effective, ultimately setting a new benchmark for what AI can do across industries.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But what's perhaps even more exciting is the next chapter—Llama 4. Zuckerberg talked about how they’re training Llama 4 on a cluster of more than 100,000 H100 GPUs, making it one of the largest and most powerful AI models ever. Early next year, the smaller Llama 4 models will be ready, promising better reasoning capabilities, new modalities, and faster responses. This push for open-source AI models could mean lower costs and more trustworthiness, as these models will be available to developers across the world, shaping the future of AI integration.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, switching gears a bit to augmented reality. One of the standout moments from the earnings call was Meta’s new developments in wearables, specifically their collaboration with Ray-Ban on the Meta smart glasses. These glasses are not just for taking photos or making calls anymore; they now integrate Meta AI, allowing users to interact with their environment in real-time. You can ask questions, get reminders, and even receive real-time translations—all while just wearing your glasses. They’re essentially bringing the power of a virtual assistant into your daily life, hands-free.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And if you think that's impressive, Zuckerberg also hinted at their first full holographic AR glasses, named Orion. These glasses represent the culmination of a decade of research and show a future where AR and the physical world blend seamlessly. Imagine being able to feel present with anyone, anywhere, just by wearing glasses that project a holographic representation of that person. This might still sound a bit futuristic, but Meta is making it happen—step by step.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: They also released the Quest 3S headset, which takes mixed reality to another level. It’s a more affordable version of the Quest 3, featuring high-quality color pass-through and a new chipset. At just $300, Meta is making sure that mixed reality is within reach for more people than ever, which is going to be particularly exciting as we head into the holiday season.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Meta's overall vision seems to center on creating more connected, immersive, and intelligent digital experiences. Whether it’s their AI models revolutionizing user interaction or their AR glasses pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in wearables, it’s clear that Meta is all in on defining the next major computing platform. And with all these developments, the question isn't if they'll succeed—but how quickly we'll be able to adapt to this new era of technology.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So that wraps up today’s episode of 'Life is Artificial'. If you enjoyed this dive into Meta’s Q3 2024 earnings and their ambitious plans for AI and AR, make sure to subscribe and leave a review. The future of computing is taking shape right before our eyes, and it’s an exciting time to stay informed and curious. I’m your host, signing off—until next time, stay curious, stay innovative.
